captions.text:
In addition to scientific equipment, the Voyager
spacecraft each carry, out beyond the solar

system, a golden record encoding information
about the earth and our human civilization.

These time capsules contain examples of the
best aspects of humanity - language, music,

art, and scientific achievements. Environmental
destruction, war and cable tv didn't make
the list. Neither did garbage.

And yet, every single time you throw something
away, you're contributing to a collective

time capsule. Because buried deep within the
landfills that dot the Earth lies precious

information about who we are, how we live
and what we really care about.

Archaeologists use heaps of trash to study
people and culture, and even have a special,

nice-sounding name for garbage piles: middens.
In one midden near Rome, archeologists uncovered

25 million containers for carrying olive oil,
telling us that Romans used a LOT of olive

oil but almost none of it came from Rome - most
was from Spain and Egypt. And we know from

shell middens that the Maori people of New
Zealand hunted moa and seals early on, but

later had to switch to fish, shellfish, and
small birds as the moa and seals became overhunted.

Digging through more recent history, a midden
outside of George Washington's home revealed

the belt buckles he wore, the china he used,
and the meat he and his guests ate off of
that china.

Even now, in our era of modern record keeping
and data, we may need to look through the

garbage to see what we're really like. In
the 1980's, there was huge outcry about the

gross quantity of garbage humans were making,
with many environmental groups painting a

picture of disposable diapers and fast food
packaging filling up our landfills. It's true

that we were producing a lot of trash, but
when researchers examined what was in those

landfills, diapers and fast food containers
accounted for less than 2 percent of new landfill

volume. The majority was construction waste
and paper.

Around the same time, a professor in Tucson
interviewed people about their eating habits,

then went through their trash to see what
they threw away. It turns out that people

and their garbage tell two very different
stories. People overreported healthy foods,

and underreported foods they considered bad.
For example, participants reported drinking

only half as much alcohol as the bottles in
their trash indicated. And everybody underreported

how much fat they ate -- except people who
had lived through WWII. Those generations

tended to overreport butter, which was heavily
rationed during the war and consequently considered
valuable and healthful.

So a survey or carefully crafted time capsule
is probably biased towards the best parts

of our lives - the parts we want people to
remember and extraterrestrials to know about.
But our trash doesn't lie.

comments.text:
Trash does not lie, but -- since recycling diverts a significant chunk of 
the waste stream -- it tells a seriously distorted truth.

For example, a community of upper middle class drunks who recycle all their 
glass would seem to be tee-totalers, and a lower class town that does not 
recycle it's beer cans would look like a bunch of drunks in comparison.﻿

comments.text:
I think the dumbest thing humanity has ever done was to throw all that 
information into space like that, for whoever to find. What the hell were 
they thinking? "Hey, just in case we are not alone in the universe, let's 
dump a whole lot of information about us, including where our planet is 
located, how our DNA works and examples of the technology we developed. 
It's not like there could exist a more advanced population out there who 
would want to use that information against us and possibly wipe us the fuck 
out of existence, right?"﻿
comments.author: Knucklehand

comments.text:
+Yeh Roddy
 Perhaps, but there is no reason to make the task easier for them, is it? 
Also, it is not that unlikely that an outsider civilization would want to 
destroy us, hell, just take a look at humanity. We destroy ourselves, 
within our very own planet, with dumb wars and useless politics. It makes 
you wonder if we'll even be around for long enough to be subject of a 
possible alien threat... My point is that I see no good in throwing all 
this information about ourselves into the unknown like that, at least no 
more good than harm. To illustrate that, just imagine you woke up lost in a 
dense forest that you have never been to before and know nothing about. As 
far as you know, there could be all kinds of wild beasts out there that 
could threat you right? In this scenario, would you want to scream and wave 
your arms saying "hey, I'm here, look at me!" for no reason? Sure, there 
could be someone friendly looking for you (a rescue team or, in the context 
of the subject, a good-hearted civilization that could help us solve some 
of our problems) but I believe that it's more likely that you will catch 
the attention of a hostile creature looking for easy prey. Yes, not the 
best of analogies, but I think it delivers what I want to convey. I'm just 
saying that humanity shouldn't venture in the unknown exposing everything 
about itself like that. That shouldn't be very hard to agree with. Would 
you give your phone number and home address to a total stranger whose 
intentions you don t know?
comments.author: Knucklehand

and conflict).

smart. No "intelligent" species would ever send out a record listing of 
what they are made of, their way of life, strengths and weaknesses, and 
WHERE THEY ARE! Life on this planet is harsh and it's a strong indication 
that life elsewhere would be just as if not more brutal. Whatever species 
has reached the top of its respective food chain would be just as if not 
more ferocious than us humans. The last thing you want to do in the dark is 
give away your position! This could end up being the biggest mistake in 
history...﻿
